comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: I beg to disagree, this is George Street, looking south towards King Street and the Town Hall. The Queen Victoria Markets (right background) and the tram tracks give it away. The street disappearing to the right foreground is Barrack Street.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] In tramway-speak, do they call the pylons "catenaries" ? A word I hadn't heard of until today, and according to Wikipedia it refers to the natural hanging curve - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catenary . I have learnt something; the day has not been entirely wasted!

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Thank you for your info, we'll update the caption. 

Like [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I was unaware of the word 'catenary'.

AB

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: A catenary curve is a geometric/physics term for the natural hang line of a wire/rope/cable/chain/etc. Different railways around the world have (and had) different terms for the parts of their infrastructure. RailCorp currently terms the hanging wires Catenary, the wire in contact with the pantograph the Touch Wire, the support structure the Portal (or mast/boom/drop for a one-sided support). A generic term for the steel support of wires is stanchion.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content:
The vertical structures supporting the wires are usually called "stanchions' or "staunchions".
Catenary refers to the supporting wires which hang in a curved shape and support the actual contact wires for the tram which need to be horizontal.
